fields.descriptive_line: Cast bronze removable chamber for a breech loading swivel gun, Japan, possibly 16th century or later
fields.physical_description:
[breeches (barrel components)] Cylindrical cast bronze flask for a breech loading swivel gun with a loop handle. The rear is stepped with a beveled base for manouevring into and securing into the chamber with a wooden wedge. A central, longitudinal casting seam is visible around much of the body. A vertical cast panel acts as a shield for the hand and a means of locking the front into the breech of the gun. 
The bore is a simple cylinder and not chambered, but the muzzle is stepped to be inserted firmly into the breech of the gun. Three vertical rows of kanji characters run down the body to the right of the handle. The vent hole is located to the rear on the right hand side of the loop handle. It is partially blocked on the outside by a metallic plug.
fields.dimensions: [breeches (barrel components)] Length: 7.25 in Taken from Register, Diameter: 3 in Taken from Register, Diameter: 1.25 in Bore. Taken from Register, Depth: 6 in Taken from Register
fields.marks:
[breeches (barrel components)] inscription in kanji down body  "ten catties in weight taking a charge of three momme of gunpowder"
[breeches (barrel components)] inscription in kanji  signed by "the craftsman Yoshikane"
fields.public_access_description: This container held a gunpowder charge and ball and was placed into the breech of a small calibre cannon. The flask was held in place with a wooden wedge and the charge ignited through the vent hole. This form of artillery loading was first developed in the 1400s and was commonly used on ship-borne anti-personnel swivel guns. The practical limitations of the mechanism meant that it could not fire projectiles larger than 4lbs in weight. It was probably introduced to Japan from mainland China or by Portuguese traders in the mid 16th century.
fields.history_note:
From the Shimura Collection
[breeches (barrel components)] Historical significance: As a result of the pressure to find metals to supply the war effort during World War II, a large quantity of historical bronze sculptures, lanterns, bells and cannon were melted down by the authorities making this a rare survivor of Japanese bronze artillery.
fields.historical_context_note:
Breech loading swivel guns were introduced by the Portuguese into Japan in the 16th century, and are documented in Japan by the 1560's. One name for them was 'Ozutsu' Lit: 'big tube'. Despite technical limitations (gaseous escape and the weight of the chamber) the breech loading swivel was favoured as an anti-personnel weapon. They were used for the defence of warships and were mounted on fortifications. The removable chambers gave it a high rate of fire and it remained in favour in Asia into the 20th century. One example of a Japanese breech loading swivel gun, with a 47mm calibre can be see at the Musee de l'Armee, Paris.
[breeches (barrel components)] This is one of several flasks that would have been used to load a small calibre swivel gun, probably based on the Spanish or Portuguese type known as a verso. Such swivel guns could be fired rapidly and reloaded quickly and were widely used as anti-personnel weapons for the defence of shipping.
The vent hole on European breech chambers is usually situated to the left of the handle. There is a small pit (now blocked) on the right hand side below the inscription which may be the vent.
In Europe, forged iron chambered swivel guns were made by competent blacksmiths. Unlike other examples of Japanese bronze cannon casting, this piece has a rough and ready workman-like appearance which may signify similar humble origins.
